Tailwind Basics

Tailwind CSS works very differently from normal CSS and Instead of writing CSS files and class names, you style elements directly in HTML using small utility classes.

At first this looks messy, but it actually makes things faster and easier once you get used to it.

---

 Utility Classes

Each Tailwind class usually does one thing.

For example:

- bg-blue-500 → background color  
- text-white → text color  
- p-4 → padding  
- rounded → border radius

Introduction to Tailwind CSS

Tailwind CSS is a utility-first CSS framework that enables developers to build modern, responsive user interfaces rapidly by applying pre-defined classes directly in HTML. Unlike traditional CSS frameworks, Tailwind emphasizes atomic, reusable utility classes rather than pre-styled components. This gives you full control over design while keeping your code concise and maintainable.

Responsive Design

Tailwind CSS follows a mobile-first approach to responsive design. This means that styles are applied for mobile screens by default, and you can add modifiers for larger screens. The framework provides responsive breakpoints that you can use to adjust your design at different screen sizes.

---

 1. Breakpoints

Tailwind comes with five default breakpoints:

| Prefix | Minimum Width | Description |
|--------|---------------|-------------|
| sm:  | 640px         | Small screen

Spacing (Margin & Padding)

Tailwind CSS provides a flexible spacing system for margins, padding, gaps, and more. Spacing is based on a scale, where the default unit is 0.25rem (4px).

---

 1. Padding

Use p- classes to apply padding:

html
<div class="p-4 bg-gray-200"
  Padding on all sides (1rem)
</div


- p-0 → 0 padding
- p-1 → 0.25rem
- p-2 → 0.5rem
- p-4 → 1rem
- p-8 → 2rem

 Padding on Specific Sides

- pt- → padding-top
- pr- → padding-right
- pb- → padding-bottom
- pl- → padding-left
